clinical_study.brief_title: Pregabalin for Treatment of Patients With Postherpetic Neuralgia (PHN)
clinical_study.official_title: An 8-week Randomized, Double Blind, Multi-center, Placebo-controlled Study To Evaluate The Efficacy, Safety And Tolerability Of Pregabalin ( 300mg/Day ) Using A Fixed Dosing Schedule In The Treatment Of Subjects With Postherpetic Neuralgia ( Phn )

brief_summary.textblock: To prove pregabalin is effective in relieving pain compared with placebo in subjects with postherpetic neuralgia (PHN).

primary_outcome.description: The daily pain rating scale (DPRS) consists of an 11-point numeric scale ranging from 0 (no pain) to 10 (worst possible pain). Participants described their pain during the past 24 hours by choosing the appropriate number between 0 and 10.

primary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Mean Pain Score at Endpoint
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline until end of fixed dose phase (Day 57/Week 8)/Early Termination (Study Endpoint)
primary_outcome.description: The daily pain rating scale (DPRS) consists of an 11-point numeric scale ranging from 0 ("no pain") to 10 ("worst possible pain"). Participants described their pain during the past 24 hours by choosing the appropriate number between 0 and 10. The mean endpoint pain score was obtained from the last 7 available DPRS scores of the daily pain diary while the participant was on study medication, up to and including the day after the last Week 8 (Day 57) dose.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Weekly Mean Pain Score at Weeks 1 to 8
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline and weekly from Weeks 1 to 8
secondary_outcome.description: The DPRS consists of an 11-point numeric scale ranging from 0 ("no pain") to 10 ("worst possible pain"). Participants described their pain during the past 24 hours by choosing the appropriate number between 0 and 10. The weekly mean pain score was the sum of the daily scores divided by the number of diary entries during that week.

secondary_outcome.measure: Baseline Mean Sleep Interference Score
secondary_outcome.description: Pain-related sleep interference was assessed on an 11-point numerical rating scale ranging from 0 (did not interfere with sleep) to 10 (completely interfered [unable to sleep due to pain]). Participants were to describe how their pain had interfered with their sleep during the past 24 hours by choosing the appropriate number between 0 and 10.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Mean Sleep Interference Score at Endpoint
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline until end of fixed dose phase (Day 57/Week 8)/Early Termination (Study Endpoint)
secondary_outcome.description: Pain-related sleep interference was assessed on an 11-point numerical rating scale ranging from 0 (did not interfere with sleep) to 10 (completely interfered [unable to sleep due to pain]). Participants were to describe how their pain had interfered with their sleep during the past 24 hours by choosing the appropriate number between 0 and 10. The mean endpoint score was obtained from the last 7 available scores of the daily diary while the participant was on study medication, up to and including the day after the last Week 8 (Day 57) dose.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Weekly Mean Sleep Interference Scores at Weeks 1 to 8
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline and weekly from Weeks 1 to 8
secondary_outcome.description: Pain-related sleep interference was assessed on an 11-point numerical rating scale ranging from 0 (did not interfere with sleep) to 10 (completely interfered [unable to sleep due to pain]). Participants were to describe how their pain had interfered with their sleep during the past 24 hours by choosing the appropriate number between 0 and 10. The weekly mean score was the sum of the daily scores divided by the number of diary entries during that week.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of 30 Percent (%) Responders at Endpoint
secondary_outcome.time_frame: End of fixed dose phase (Day 57/Week 8)/Early Termination (Study Endpoint)
secondary_outcome.description: The DPRS consists of an 11-point numeric scale ranging from 0 ("no pain") to 10 ("worst possible pain"). Participants described their pain during the past 24 hours by choosing the appropriate number between 0 and 10. A 30% responder was a participant who had 30% reduction or more in mean pain score at the end of the fixed dose phase (Day 57/Week 8)/Early Termination (Study Endpoint) compared to baseline.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Short Form McGill Pain Questionnaire (SF-MPQ) Score at Weeks 1, 3, 5, and 8
secondary_outcome.description: SF-MPQ was assessed according to the participant's answer to the SF-MPQ questionnaire. The score for each composite scale (sensory, affective, and total) was derived by summing the reported intensity value for each item within a particular scale where None=0, Mild=1, Moderate=2, and Severe=3. The sensory score was the sum of the scores of the first 11 pain descriptors (throbbing, shooting, stabbing, sharp, cramping, gnawing, hot-burning, aching, heavy, tender, and splitting) and could range from 0-33. The affective score was the sum of the scores of the last 4 pain descriptors (tiring-exhausting, sickening, fearful, and punishing-cruel) and could range from 0-12. The total score was the sum of the scores of all 15 pain descriptors and could range from 0 to 45. Higher scores indicated greater pain.

secondary_outcome.measure: Baseline Pain Visual Analogue Scale (VAS) and Present Pain Intensity (PPI) Scale
secondary_outcome.description: The VAS was part of the Short Form McGill Pain Questionnaire (SF-MPQ) scale and reflected the overall pain intensity score, The pain VAS was a horizontal line; 100 millimeters (mm) in length, was self-administered by the participant in order to rate pain from 0 (no pain) to 100 (worst possible pain). The PPI was part of the SF-MPQ scale and measured the participant's present pain intensity on a 6-point scale ranging from 0 (no pain) to 5 (excruciating).

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Pain VAS From the SF-MPQ at Endpoint
secondary_outcome.description: The VAS was part of the SF-MPQ scale and reflected the overall pain intensity score. The pain VAS was a horizontal line; 100 mm in length, was self-administered by the participant in order to rate pain from 0 (no pain) to 100 (worst possible pain).

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in PPI Scale From the SF-MPQ at Endpoint
secondary_outcome.description: The PPI was part of the SF-MPQ scale and measured the participant's present pain intensity on a 6-point scale ranging from 0 (no pain) to 5 (excruciating).

secondary_outcome.measure: Baseline Medical Outcomes Study (MOS)-Sleep Scale Scores
secondary_outcome.description: The MOS-Sleep Scale was a participant-rated questionnaire consisting of 12 items that assessed key constructs of sleep. Instrument scoring yielded 7 subscales (sleep disturbance, snoring, awaken short of breath or with a headache, quantity of sleep, optimal sleep, sleep adequacy, and somnolence) as well as a 9-item overall sleep problems index. The total score ranged from 0 to 100. With the exception of sleep adequacy, optimal sleep, and quantity, higher scores reflected greater impairment in the MOS-Sleep subscales. The MOS-Sleep Scale was used to evaluate sleep during the previous week.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in MOS-Sleep Scale, Sleep Disturbance Score at Endpoint
secondary_outcome.description: The MOS-Sleep Scale was a participant-rated questionnaire consisting of 12 items that assessed key constructs of sleep. Instrument scoring yielded 7 subscales (sleep disturbance, snoring, awaken short of breath or with a headache, quantity of sleep, optimal sleep, sleep adequacy, and somnolence) as well as a 9-item overall sleep problems index. The total score ranged from 0 to 100. For sleep disturbance, the subscale score also ranged from 0 to 100, with higher scores representing greater sleep disturbance.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in MOS-Sleep Scale, Snoring Score at Endpoint
secondary_outcome.description: The MOS-Sleep Scale was a participant-rated questionnaire consisting of 12 items that assessed key constructs of sleep. Instrument scoring yielded 7 subscales (sleep disturbance, snoring, awaken short of breath or with a headache, quantity of sleep, optimal sleep, sleep adequacy, and somnolence) as well as a 9-item overall sleep problems index. The total score ranged from 0 to 100. The snoring subscale score also ranged from 0 to 100, with lower scores indicating less snoring.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in MOS-Sleep Scale, Awaken Short of Breath Score at Endpoint
secondary_outcome.description: The MOS-Sleep Scale was a participant-rated questionnaire consisting of 12 items that assessed key constructs of sleep. Instrument scoring yielded 7 subscales (sleep disturbance, snoring, awaken short of breath or with a headache, quantity of sleep, optimal sleep, sleep adequacy, and somnolence) as well as a 9-item overall sleep problems index. The total score ranged from 0 to 100. The awaken short of breath subscale also ranged from 0 to 100, with lower scores indicating less difficulty in breathing.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in MOS-Sleep Scale, Quantity of Sleep Score at Endpoint
secondary_outcome.description: The MOS-Sleep Scale was a participant-rated questionnaire consisting of 12 items that assessed key constructs of sleep. Instrument scoring yielded 7 subscales (sleep disturbance, snoring, awaken short of breath or with a headache, quantity of sleep, optimal sleep, sleep adequacy, and somnolence) as well as a 9-item overall sleep problems index. The total score ranged from 0 to 100. The MOS Sleep Quantity sub-scale scores ranged from 0 to 24 (number of hours slept).

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Participants Who Had Optimal Sleep at Endpoint
secondary_outcome.description: The MOS-Sleep Scale was a participant-rated questionnaire consisting of 12 items that assessed key constructs of sleep. Instrument scoring yielded 7 subscales (sleep disturbance, snoring, awaken short of breath or with a headache, quantity of sleep, optimal sleep, sleep adequacy, and somnolence) as well as a 9-item overall sleep problems index. The total score ranged from 0 to 100. The MOS optimal sleep subscale was a binary outcome derived from the sleep quantity responses: the response was YES if sleep quantity was 7 or 8 hours per night.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in MOS-Sleep Scale, Sleep Adequacy Score at Endpoint
secondary_outcome.description: The MOS-Sleep Scale was a participant-rated questionnaire consisting of 12 items that assessed key constructs of sleep. Instrument scoring yielded 7 subscales (sleep disturbance, snoring, awaken short of breath or with a headache, quantity of sleep, optimal sleep, sleep adequacy, and somnolence) as well as a 9-item overall sleep problems index. The total score ranged from 0 to 100. The sleep adequacy subscale also ranged from 0 to 100, with higher scores indicating greater sleep adequacy.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in MOS-Sleep Scale, Somnolence Score at Endpoint
secondary_outcome.description: The MOS-Sleep Scale was a participant-rated questionnaire consisting of 12 items that assessed key constructs of sleep. Instrument scoring yielded 7 subscales (sleep disturbance, snoring, awaken short of breath or with a headache, quantity of sleep, optimal sleep, sleep adequacy, and somnolence) as well as a 9-item overall sleep problems index. The total score ranged from 0 to 100. The somnolence subscale score also ranged from 0 to 100, with lower scores indicating less somnolence.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in MOS-Sleep Scale, Sleep Problems Index Score at Endpoint
secondary_outcome.description: The MOS-Sleep Scale was a participant-rated questionnaire consisting of 12 items that assessed key constructs of sleep. Instrument scoring yielded 7 subscales (sleep disturbance, snoring, awaken short of breath or with a headache, quantity of sleep, optimal sleep, sleep adequacy, and somnolence) as well as a 9-item overall sleep problems index. The total score ranged from 0 to 100. The sleep problems index subscale score also ranged from 0 to 100, with lower scores indicating fewer sleep problems.

secondary_outcome.measure: Clinical Global Impression of Change (CGIC) Score at Endpoint
secondary_outcome.description: The CGIC was a clinician-rated global measure that provided a clinically relevant and easy to interpret account of a clinician's perception of the clinical importance of the participant's improvement or worsening during their involvement in a clinical study. Clinicians rated the participant's overall improvement on a 7-point scale where scores ranged from 1 (very much improved) to 7 (very much worse).

secondary_outcome.measure: Patient Global Impression of Change (PGIC) Score at Endpoint
secondary_outcome.description: The PGIC was a participant-rated global measure that provided a clinically relevant and easy to interpret account of a participant's perception of the clinical importance of their own improvement or worsening during their involvement in a clinical study. Participants rated their overall improvement on a 7-point scale where scores ranged from 1 (very much improved) to 7 (very much worse).

secondary_outcome.measure: Baseline Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS) Scores
secondary_outcome.description: The HADS was a self-administered questionnaire that consisted of 2 subscales, 1 measuring anxiety (HADS-A Scale) and the other measuring depression (HADS-D Scale). Each subscale comprised of 7 items; participants assessed how each item applied to them on a scale of 0 (no presence of anxiety or depression) to 3 (severe feeling of anxiety or depression). Subscores from HADS-A (Anxiety) and HADS-D (Depression) were not to be combined. The interpretation of each HADS subscales was as follows: 0-7 normal, 8-10 mild, 11-14 moderate and 15-21 severe.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in HADS Anxiety Total Score at Endpoint
secondary_outcome.description: The HADS was a self-administered questionnaire that consisted of 2 subscales, 1 measuring anxiety (HADS-A Scale) and the other measuring depression (HADS-D Scale). Each subscale was comprised of 7 items; participants assessed how each item applied to them on a scale of 0 (no presence of anxiety or depression) to 3 (severe feeling of anxiety or depression). Subscores from HADS-A (Anxiety) and HADS-D (Depression) were not to be combined. The interpretation of each HADS subscales was as follows: 0-7 normal, 8-10 mild, 11-14 moderate and 15-21 severe.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in HADS Depression Total Score at Endpoint
secondary_outcome.description: The HADS was a self-administered questionnaire that consisted of 2 subscales, 1 measuring anxiety (HADS-A Scale) and the other measuring depression (HADS-D Scale). Each subscale was comprised of 7 items; participants assessed how each item applied to them on a scale of 0 (no presence of anxiety or depression) to 3 (severe feeling of anxiety or depression). Subscores from HADS-A (Anxiety) and HADS-D (Depression) were not to be combined. The interpretation of each HADS subscales was as follows: 0-7 normal, 8-10 mild, 11-14 moderate and 15-21 severe.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Male or female Chinese subjects, ages ≥18 at screening
- Subjects with symptoms of neuropathic pain associated with postherpetic neuralgia (PHN). Subjects must have pain present for ﹥3 months after healing of the acute herpes zoster skin rash
- At screening (V1), subjects must have a score ≥40mm on the 100-mm visual analog scale (VAS) of the Short Form-McGill Pain Questionnaire (SF-MPQ, see Appendix 3)
- At randomization (V2), subjects must have a score ≥40mm on the 100-mm visual analog scale (VAS) of the Short Form-McGill Pain Questionnaire (SF-MPQ, see Appendix 3)
- At randomization (V2), subjects must have completed at least 5 daily pain diaries (DPRS, see Appendix 2) and have an average daily pain score ≥4 over the past 7 days
Exclusion Criteria:
- Subjects who demonstrate a high response to placebo, with 30% decrease on the Pain Visual Analog Scale (VAS) at randomization as compared to screening
- Subjects who have a high variability in pain scores during the 1 week screening period, with any difference between two scores ﹥3

participant_flow.recruitment_details: 223 participants were randomized, as stated on clinicaltrials.gov. However, 1 was randomized by mistake, was considered a screen failure, and was not given any medication. As such, the actual number of participants randomized and assigned to treatment was 222.

group.title: Pregabalin
group.description: Participants received 1 matching placebo capsule twice a day (BID) for 1 week (run-in period), followed by an 8-week double-blind treatment phase (1-week dose-titration phase where participants received pregabalin 150 milligram [mg] per day in the form of 75 mg BID and a 7-week fixed dose phase where participants received pregabalin 300 mg per day in the form of 150 mg BID), and a 1-week taper-off phase where participants received pregabalin 150 mg per day (in the form of 75 mg BID).

group.title: Placebo
group.description: Participants received matching placebo capsule(s) for a period of 10 weeks.

baseline.population: All randomized and treated participants were included in the baseline characteristics summarization.

measure.title: Change From Baseline in Weekly Mean Sleep Interference Scores at Weeks 1 to 8
measure.description: Pain-related sleep interference was assessed on an 11-point numerical rating scale ranging from 0 (did not interfere with sleep) to 10 (completely interfered [unable to sleep due to pain]). Participants were to describe how their pain had interfered with their sleep during the past 24 hours by choosing the appropriate number between 0 and 10. The weekly mean score was the sum of the daily scores divided by the number of diary entries during that week.
measure.population: The FAS population consisted of all participants randomized to treatment that received at least 1 dose of study medication.

outcome.title: Percentage of 30 Percent (%) Responders at Endpoint
outcome.description: The DPRS consists of an 11-point numeric scale ranging from 0 (“no pain”) to 10 (“worst possible pain”). Participants described their pain during the past 24 hours by choosing the appropriate number between 0 and 10. A 30% responder was a participant who had 30% reduction or more in mean pain score at the end of the fixed dose phase (Day 57/Week 8)/Early Termination (Study Endpoint) compared to baseline.
outcome.time_frame: End of fixed dose phase (Day 57/Week 8)/Early Termination (Study Endpoint)
outcome.population: All participants in the FAS population (all participants randomized to treatment that received at least 1 dose of study medication) who had available data for this outcome measure. The LOCF method was used.

outcome.title: Change From Baseline in Short Form McGill Pain Questionnaire (SF-MPQ) Score at Weeks 1, 3, 5, and 8
outcome.description: SF-MPQ was assessed according to the participant’s answer to the SF-MPQ questionnaire. The score for each composite scale (sensory, affective, and total) was derived by summing the reported intensity value for each item within a particular scale where None=0, Mild=1, Moderate=2, and Severe=3. The sensory score was the sum of the scores of the first 11 pain descriptors (throbbing, shooting, stabbing, sharp, cramping, gnawing, hot-burning, aching, heavy, tender, and splitting) and could range from 0-33. The affective score was the sum of the scores of the last 4 pain descriptors (tiring-exhausting, sickening, fearful, and punishing-cruel) and could range from 0-12. The total score was the sum of the scores of all 15 pain descriptors and could range from 0 to 45. Higher scores indicated greater pain.
outcome.population: The FAS population consisted of all participants randomized to treatment that received at least 1 dose of study medication. N=the number of participants who were evaluable for this measure at the given time point.

outcome.title: Baseline Pain Visual Analogue Scale (VAS) and Present Pain Intensity (PPI) Scale
outcome.description: The VAS was part of the Short Form McGill Pain Questionnaire (SF-MPQ) scale and reflected the overall pain intensity score, The pain VAS was a horizontal line; 100 millimeters (mm) in length, was self-administered by the participant in order to rate pain from 0 (no pain) to 100 (worst possible pain). The PPI was part of the SF-MPQ scale and measured the participant's present pain intensity on a 6-point scale ranging from 0 (no pain) to 5 (excruciating).
outcome.population: The FAS population consisted of all participants randomized to treatment that received at least 1 dose of study medication. The LOCF method was used in the analysis of this outcome measure. Number of participants evaluable for PPI=110, 108

outcome.title: Baseline Medical Outcomes Study (MOS)-Sleep Scale Scores
outcome.description: The MOS-Sleep Scale was a participant-rated questionnaire consisting of 12 items that assessed key constructs of sleep. Instrument scoring yielded 7 subscales (sleep disturbance, snoring, awaken short of breath or with a headache, quantity of sleep, optimal sleep, sleep adequacy, and somnolence) as well as a 9-item overall sleep problems index. The total score ranged from 0 to 100. With the exception of sleep adequacy, optimal sleep, and quantity, higher scores reflected greater impairment in the MOS-Sleep subscales. The MOS-Sleep Scale was used to evaluate sleep during the previous week.
outcome.population: The FAS population consisted of all participants randomized to treatment that received at least 1 dose of study medication. The LOCF method was used in the analysis of this outcome measure.

outcome.title: Percentage of Participants Who Had Optimal Sleep at Endpoint
outcome.description: The MOS-Sleep Scale was a participant-rated questionnaire consisting of 12 items that assessed key constructs of sleep. Instrument scoring yielded 7 subscales (sleep disturbance, snoring, awaken short of breath or with a headache, quantity of sleep, optimal sleep, sleep adequacy, and somnolence) as well as a 9-item overall sleep problems index. The total score ranged from 0 to 100. The MOS optimal sleep subscale was a binary outcome derived from the sleep quantity responses: the response was YES if sleep quantity was 7 or 8 hours per night.

measure.title: Change From Baseline in MOS-Sleep Scale, Somnolence Score at Endpoint
measure.description: The MOS-Sleep Scale was a participant-rated questionnaire consisting of 12 items that assessed key constructs of sleep. Instrument scoring yielded 7 subscales (sleep disturbance, snoring, awaken short of breath or with a headache, quantity of sleep, optimal sleep, sleep adequacy, and somnolence) as well as a 9-item overall sleep problems index. The total score ranged from 0 to 100. The somnolence subscale score also ranged from 0 to 100, with lower scores indicating less somnolence.
measure.population: All participants in the FAS population (all participants randomized to treatment that received at least 1 dose of study medication) who had available data for this outcome measure.

analysis.groups_desc: Analysis performed using a general linear model with treatment and center as factors, and baseline value as a covariate.
analysis.p_value_desc: Analysis was two-sided and performed at the 0.05 significance level.

outcome.title: Change From Baseline in MOS-Sleep Scale, Sleep Problems Index Score at Endpoint

The total score ranged from 0 to 100. The sleep problems index subscale score also ranged from 0 to 100, with lower scores indicating fewer sleep problems.
outcome.population: All participants in the FAS population (all participants randomized to treatment that received at least 1 dose of study medication) who had available data for this outcome measure.

group.title: Pregabalin
group.description: Participants received 1 matching placebo capsule twice a day (BID) for 1 week (run-in period), followed by an 8-week double-blind treatment phase (1-week dose-titration phase where participants received pregabalin 150 milligram [mg] per day in the form of 75 mg BID and a 7-week fixed dose phase where participants received pregabalin 300 mg per day in the form of 150 mg BID), and a 1-week taper-off phase where participants received pregabalin 150 mg per day (in the form of 75 mg BID).

group.title: Placebo
group.description: Participants received matching placebo capsule(s) for a period of 10 weeks

outcome.title: Clinical Global Impression of Change (CGIC) Score at Endpoint
outcome.description: The CGIC was a clinician-rated global measure that provided a clinically relevant and easy to interpret account of a clinician’s perception of the clinical importance of the participant's improvement or worsening during their involvement in a clinical study. Clinicians rated the participant's overall improvement on a 7-point scale where scores ranged from 1 (very much improved) to 7 (very much worse).
outcome.population: All participants in the FAS population (all participants randomized to treatment that received at least 1 dose of study medication) who had available data for this outcome measure.

outcome.title: Patient Global Impression of Change (PGIC) Score at Endpoint
outcome.description: The PGIC was a participant-rated global measure that provided a clinically relevant and easy to interpret account of a participant’s perception of the clinical importance of their own improvement or worsening during their involvement in a clinical study. Participants rated their overall improvement on a 7-point scale where scores ranged from 1 (very much improved) to 7 (very much worse).
outcome.population: All participants in the FAS population (all participants randomized to treatment that received at least 1 dose of study medication) who had available data for this outcome measure.

outcome.title: Baseline Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS) Scores
outcome.description: The HADS was a self-administered questionnaire that consisted of 2 subscales, 1 measuring anxiety (HADS-A Scale) and the other measuring depression (HADS-D Scale). Each subscale comprised of 7 items; participants assessed how each item applied to them on a scale of 0 (no presence of anxiety or depression) to 3 (severe feeling of anxiety or depression). Subscores from HADS-A (Anxiety) and HADS-D (Depression) were not to be combined. The interpretation of each HADS subscales was as follows: 0-7 normal, 8-10 mild, 11-14 moderate and 15-21 severe.
outcome.population: All participants in the FAS population (all participants randomized to treatment that received at least 1 dose of study medication) who had available data for this outcome measure. The LOCF method was used.

reported_events.desc: The same event may appear as both an AE and a SAE. However, what is presented are distinct events. An event may be categorized as serious in one participant and as nonserious in another, or one participant may have experienced both a serious and nonserious event during the study. All treated participants were included in the analysis.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: Pfizer has the right to review disclosures, requesting a delay of less than 60 days. Investigator will postpone single center publications until after disclosure of pooled data (all sites), less than 12 months from study completion/termination at all participating sites. Investigator may not disclose previously undisclosed confidential information other than study results.
